channel.title: What are some good cars
channel.description: Alright so Im looking for a car to drive to school next year when I become 16. I want something that looks good, is reliable, but is also under $12,000. Lets just leave out ford because my father will never buy one of those unless you can get them for $100. Any responses will be appreciated and i will rep++ good answers.

item.title: What are some good cars
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

It says it has a trip calculator and it says it gets 16.7 mpg but I will be only driving too and from school so im not too worried. It says its suppose to get 20 mpg city though.

item.title: What are some good cars
item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282
item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:55, topic:275734”][quote author=sanga282 link=topic=364220.msg2800472#msg2800472 date=1243357484]

mopar, an F1 car looks better than a charger though

It looks like the cockpit of a jet on wheels. Not exactly stylish. But then it’s not meant to be.

The point of the design is Aerodynamics. So you’re right, you can’t compare them.

you can seeing as how the charger was supposed to be designed for aerodynamics but the guy who made it cocked it up alot, and an F1 car just lookers sexier
[/quote]

The charger was not designed with F1 aerodynamics in mind, the 1970 Plymouth Superbird was designed with aerodynamics for racing in mind though, which is why I originally said you can’t compare it to regular cars.[/quote]
No it was just designed to be aerodynamically efficient but the guy didn’t actually understand aerodynamics. And looks for a car are something that aren’t necessarily aerodynamic related, they could’ve made the charger look like whatever they wanted but they chose that shape, F1 cars are designed for aerodynamics sure but they still have a style about them. You can compare the looks of any two similar things. You could compare the looks of a plane and a car or a boat and a jetski, sure they are designed for different purposes but styling is whatever the designer wants with whatever restrictions that mode of transport offers. Thats like saying you couldnt compare an abstract painting to a figure painting, but in fact you can because you can say that you prefer this one to that one.

Read full topic

item.title: What are some good cars
item.dc:creator: @zoltanman zoltanman
item.description:
@zoltanman wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:49, topic:275734”][quote author=Cowie` link=topic=364220.msg2795326#msg2795326 date=1243036139]

Japan makes good motorcycles, ATVs, TVs, radios, computer parts etc. But they have never, ever, made a decent car.

As far as Germans, they make good guns, and maybe their cars are decent, but compared to American cars they are insanely overpriced. For example, you can get a BMW, but for the same price you can have at least 2, maybe 3 or 4 American cars that are just as fast or faster, easier and cheaper to work on, and just as nice. So why would anyone with half a brain ever buy a German car?

reliable, look nice, good engines

not to mention luxury

American cars have all 4 of those qualities, at a fraction of the price too, so again, why?

I don’t count a plastic interior or rollcages as luxury.
Nor do I think mopar cars look nice with a 3ft spoiler on the back, or their body lines that don’t flow but instead peak off every single panel.
While I’m on the subject, a good engine doesn’t mean a massive powerplant as you americans think.

Next bullshit statement from you is welcomed.
[/quote]

The Dodge Charger SRT8 (along with pretty much all other high performance and/or luxury American cars) comes with a high quality leather interior that looks great. Roll bars? What are you talking about?

With the second line, you seem to be referring to the 1970 Plymouth Superbird, which was an all out racing car. By nascar regulations chrysler had to make one car for every dealership they owned to enter it in a nascar race. At the time they had 200 dealerships, and so they made 200 cars. That car beat both ford and chevy by a longshot and so regulations the next year pretty much banned it. You can’t really take an all out racecar and compare it with a luxury car, that would be like me comparing an F1 car to the Charger and saying the F1 is uglier.

Define ‘good engine’ then? I guess I would define it as a very reliable engine, that is easy to work on, that produces massive amounts of power. Not just at high RPMs either, but throughout the entire range. It also does all of this at a reasonable cost. Many American engines fit that description, and I’m not aware of any foreign ones that do.

Indeed Cowie, I can’t agree more.

Here is a list with worlds top 10 engines available in the U.S. market.

…snip…

Want me to go on?

Don’t get me wrong, but it’s just that USA isn’t the best anymore with cars.
And that doesn’t mean that I don’t like them! I like muscle cars.
As for the prices. It’s true that you will get more for less in a American car, but will you get the quality and reliability?

Plus almost everyone could buy an American car with a big block engine, but can you maintain it?

Again, where did you get this list and what did they use to define ‘top engine’. Refer to my note above about what I see as a ‘good engine’.

I have had a lot of experience with many different American cars and trucks, and I have found the quality and reliability to be excellent. For example my 1989 Chevrolet S10 Baja came with a nice 4.3L V6 engine, and the engine finally blew two years ago with 314,000 some-odd miles on it. When the odometer read 310,000 miles I felt confident enough in it’s reliability to take it on a 4042 mile road trip to the Grand Canyon and back, I doubt many Germans could say that about their cars, is Germany even that far across? Seems pretty high-quality to me. I have since put in a 5.7L 350ci V8 with relative ease and expect another 300,000+ miles from it. Can you do that with foreign cars?

Big block engines are very easy to maintain, much easier than german engines that are 100% computer controlled. A new air filter every 6 or 8 thousand miles, new oil and filter every 3 or 6 thousand miles (depending on conventional or synthetic) and new spark plugs and wires every 36 or so thousand miles and they will run for a very long time. My 7.4L 454 has 120,000 miles on it, and my dad’s has 150,000 miles, both still run great.[/quote]

A classic muscle car that doesn’t have all of those electronics controlling it’s engine is more consistent in bracket racing anyways.

Read full topic

item.title: What are some good cars
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Cowie`, post:45, topic:275734”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=364220.msg2789007#msg2789007 date=1242621375]

Japan makes good motorcycles, ATVs, TVs, radios, computer parts etc. But they have never, ever, made a decent car.

As far as Germans, they make good guns, and maybe their cars are decent, but compared to American cars they are insanely overpriced. For example, you can get a BMW, but for the same price you can have at least 2, maybe 3 or 4 American cars that are just as fast or faster, easier and cheaper to work on, and just as nice. So why would anyone with half a brain ever buy a German car?

reliable, look nice, good engines

not to mention luxury

American cars have all 4 of those qualities, at a fraction of the price too, so again, why?
[/quote]

I don’t count a plastic interior or rollcages as luxury.
Nor do I think mopar cars look nice with a 3ft spoiler on the back, or their body lines that don’t flow but instead peak off every single panel.
While I’m on the subject, a good engine doesn’t mean a massive powerplant as you americans think.

Next bullshit statement from you is welcomed.[/quote]

The Dodge Charger SRT8 (along with pretty much all other high performance and/or luxury American cars) comes with a high quality leather interior that looks great. Roll bars? What are you talking about?

With the second line, you seem to be referring to the 1970 Plymouth Superbird, which was an all out racing car. By nascar regulations chrysler had to make one car for every dealership they owned to enter it in a nascar race. At the time they had 200 dealerships, and so they made 200 cars. That car beat both ford and chevy by a longshot and so regulations the next year pretty much banned it. You can’t really take an all out racecar and compare it with a luxury car, that would be like me comparing an F1 car to the Charger and saying the F1 is uglier.

Define ‘good engine’ then? I guess I would define it as a very reliable engine, that is easy to work on, that produces massive amounts of power. Not just at high RPMs either, but throughout the entire range. It also does all of this at a reasonable cost. Many American engines fit that description, and I’m not aware of any foreign ones that do.

[quote=“Waffendennis, post:46, topic:275734”]Indeed Cowie, I can’t agree more.

Here is a list with worlds top 10 engines available in the U.S. market.

…snip…

Want me to go on?

Don’t get me wrong, but it’s just that USA isn’t the best anymore with cars.
And that doesn’t mean that I don’t like them! I like muscle cars.
As for the prices. It’s true that you will get more for less in a American car, but will you get the quality and reliability?

Plus almost everyone could buy an American car with a big block engine, but can you maintain it?[/quote]

Again, where did you get this list and what did they use to define ‘top engine’. Refer to my note above about what I see as a ‘good engine’.

I have had a lot of experience with many different American cars and trucks, and I have found the quality and reliability to be excellent. For example my 1989 Chevrolet S10 Baja came with a nice 4.3L V6 engine, and the engine finally blew two years ago with 314,000 some-odd miles on it. When the odometer read 310,000 miles I felt confident enough in it’s reliability to take it on a 4042 mile road trip to the Grand Canyon and back, I doubt many Germans could say that about their cars, is Germany even that far across? Seems pretty high-quality to me. I have since put in a 5.7L 350ci V8 with relative ease and expect another 300,000+ miles from it. Can you do that with foreign cars?

Big block engines are very easy to maintain, much easier than german engines that are 100% computer controlled. A new air filter every 6 or 8 thousand miles, new oil and filter every 3 or 6 thousand miles (depending on conventional or synthetic) and new spark plugs and wires every 36 or so thousand miles and they will run for a very long time. My 7.4L 454 has 120,000 miles on it, and my dad’s has 150,000 miles, both still run great.

Read full topic

item.title: What are some good cars
item.dc:creator: @zoltanman zoltanman
item.description:
@zoltanman wrote:

[quote=“Cowie`, post:45, topic:275734”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=364220.msg2789007#msg2789007 date=1242621375]

Japan makes good motorcycles, ATVs, TVs, radios, computer parts etc. But they have never, ever, made a decent car.

As far as Germans, they make good guns, and maybe their cars are decent, but compared to American cars they are insanely overpriced. For example, you can get a BMW, but for the same price you can have at least 2, maybe 3 or 4 American cars that are just as fast or faster, easier and cheaper to work on, and just as nice. So why would anyone with half a brain ever buy a German car?

reliable, look nice, good engines

not to mention luxury

American cars have all 4 of those qualities, at a fraction of the price too, so again, why?
[/quote]

I don’t count a plastic interior or rollcages as luxury.
Nor do I think mopar cars look nice with a 3ft spoiler on the back, or their body lines that don’t flow but instead peak off every single panel.
While I’m on the subject, a good engine doesn’t mean a massive powerplant as you americans think.

Next bullshit statement from you is welcomed.[/quote]

A good engine is a good engine. Both my dad’s and my cutlass have lasted over 15 years of racing. Those massive power plants come cheap. It’s a lot cheaper to make a Chevrolet engine powerful more than a four cylinder. You have to supercharge the four cylinder in some way to make up for the displacement it’s lacking. My cutlass does deep 12s in the quarter mile, that was around a $1,500 job with non-performance parts. As for a four cylinder, that’s about a $20,000 job. You may save gas, but really? You spent almost $19,000 less, I think you’re not out any money.

[quote=“Waffendennis, post:46, topic:275734”]Indeed Cowie, I can’t agree more.

Here is a list with worlds top 10 engines available in the U.S. market.

2009
Audi 2.0 L I4 FSI turbocharged DOHC
BMW 3.0 L I6 N54B30 twin turbo
BMW 3.0 L I6 BMW M57 Twin Turbo Diesel
Chrysler 5.7 L V8 Hemi
Ford 2.5 L I4 Duratec Hybrid
General Motors 3.6 L V6 Direct Injection High-Feature
Honda 3.5 L V6 J35
Hyundai Motor 4.6 L V8 Tau CVVT DOHC Engine
Toyota 3.5 L V6 2GR-FSE
Volkswagen 2.0 L I4 TDI PD Turbodiesel

Ok lets count:
3 American engines, 4 European engines, 2 Japanese engines and 1 Korean engine.
Where Audi and BMW share the top spots.

2008

2008
Audi 2.0 L I4 FSI turbocharged DOHC
BMW 3.0 L I6 N54B30 twin turbo
Mercedes-Benz 3.0 L V6 Bluetec Turbodiesel
Ford 4.6 L V8 Modular 3V SOHC
General Motors 3.6 L V6 Direct Injection High-Feature
General Motors 6.0 L V8 Vortec OHV Hybrid
Honda 3.5 L V6 J35
Mazda 2.3 L I4 DISI turbocharged DOHC
Nissan 3.7 L V6 VQ37VHR
Toyota 3.5 L V6 2GR-FSE

3 American engines, 3 European engines and 4 Japanese engines.
Yet again European power on the first three spots.

2007

2007
Audi 2.0 L I4 FSI turbocharged DOHC
BMW 3.0 L I6 N52B30
BMW 3.0 L I6 N54B30 twin turbo
Mercedes-Benz 3.0 L V6 Bluetec Turbodiesel
Chrysler 5.7 L V8 Hemi Magnum
Ford 4.6 L V8 Modular 3V SOHC
Ford 3.5 L V6 Duratec 35
Mazda 2.3 L I4 DISI turbocharged DOHC
Nissan 3.5 L V6 VQ35HR
Toyota 3.5 L V6 2GR-FSE

3 American engines, 4 European engines and 3 Japanese engines.
And yet again it’s the European market that share the top spots.

Want me to go on?

Don’t get me wrong, but it’s just that USA isn’t the best anymore with cars.
And that doesn’t mean that I don’t like them! I like muscle cars.
As for the prices. It’s true that you will get more for less in a American car, but will you get the quality and reliability?

Plus almost everyone could buy an American car with a big block engine, but can you maintain it?[/quote]

BMW has been known for electrical problems. Just might throw that out there for ya. The reliability comes with a good maintained car. Most Americans don’t get oil changes and tune ups regularly and just let their engine rot. As for the Japanese engines, that’s all you saw in the shop getting fixed.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Waffendennis Waffendennis
item.description:
@Waffendennis wrote:

Indeed Cowie, I can’t agree more.

Here is a list with worlds top 10 engines available in the U.S. market.

2009 Audi 2.0 L I4 FSI turbocharged DOHC BMW 3.0 L I6 N54B30 twin turbo BMW 3.0 L I6 BMW M57 Twin Turbo Diesel Chrysler 5.7 L V8 Hemi Ford 2.5 L I4 Duratec Hybrid General Motors 3.6 L V6 Direct Injection High-Feature Honda 3.5 L V6 J35 Hyundai Motor 4.6 L V8 Tau CVVT DOHC Engine Toyota 3.5 L V6 2GR-FSE Volkswagen 2.0 L I4 TDI PD Turbodiesel

Ok lets count:
3 American engines, 4 European engines, 2 Japanese engines and 1 Korean engine.
Where Audi and BMW share the top spots.

2008

2008 Audi 2.0 L I4 FSI turbocharged DOHC BMW 3.0 L I6 N54B30 twin turbo Mercedes-Benz 3.0 L V6 Bluetec Turbodiesel Ford 4.6 L V8 Modular 3V SOHC General Motors 3.6 L V6 Direct Injection High-Feature General Motors 6.0 L V8 Vortec OHV Hybrid Honda 3.5 L V6 J35 Mazda 2.3 L I4 DISI turbocharged DOHC Nissan 3.7 L V6 VQ37VHR Toyota 3.5 L V6 2GR-FSE

3 American engines, 3 European engines and 4 Japanese engines.
Yet again European power on the first three spots.

2007

2007 Audi 2.0 L I4 FSI turbocharged DOHC BMW 3.0 L I6 N52B30 BMW 3.0 L I6 N54B30 twin turbo Mercedes-Benz 3.0 L V6 Bluetec Turbodiesel Chrysler 5.7 L V8 Hemi Magnum Ford 4.6 L V8 Modular 3V SOHC Ford 3.5 L V6 Duratec 35 Mazda 2.3 L I4 DISI turbocharged DOHC Nissan 3.5 L V6 VQ35HR Toyota 3.5 L V6 2GR-FSE

3 American engines, 4 European engines and 3 Japanese engines.
And yet again it’s the European market that share the top spots.

Want me to go on?

Don’t get me wrong, but it’s just that USA isn’t the best anymore with cars.
And that doesn’t mean that I don’t like them! I like muscle cars.
As for the prices. It’s true that you will get more for less in a American car, but will you get the quality and reliability?

Plus almost everyone could buy an American car with a big block engine, but can you maintain it?

I was mainly pointing out that if BMW can do better with one of their production cars, why haven’t they?[/quote]
everyone in the UK drives those around didn’t you know!?
